lines.text:
[slipping on a diamond ring]
Oh, I couldn't think of accepting such a valuable gift!
But, my dear, my feeling for you is purely platonic.
Really? I've heard of platonic love, but I didn't know there was such a thing as platonic jewelry.
What am I going to be doing while you're saving your first million?
Waiting for me.

[Giggles]
Waiting isn't my idea of the king of indoor sports. I've no intention of waiting around for three or four years while you harvest an additional crop of wild oats.
I've balanced our accounts.
You're a fascinating wench, Jerry!
I'd like to make love to you till you scream for help.

[Putting her hands around her throat to pantomine stifling a scream]
Can't scream.
Who's the man?
Oh, Ted, don't be conventional!
Tell me the truth.
The truth?
[laughs]
The last thing any man wants to hear from any woman!
Oh, how do you do, Mrs. Meredith?
Just a floating grass widow.
Floats them and gets them.
Gee whiz, but I'm glad to see you. Say, I've missed you like the dickens, Helen!
All men are fair game from now on!
There's something in the way she looked at you that made me want to kill her.
Well you don't exactly take the veil when your decree is granted, you know.
What you feel for me is not love. It's the call of the gorilla to its mate.
My dear, Jerry. You American women are so cold.
Are you sure you can tell whether a woman is cold or careful?

[Long Kiss]
Wooo! My head's going 'round like a pinwheel.
And my heart's beating like a steam engine. Feel.
Ha-ha-ha. When did you first start having heart trouble?
From the first moment I met you.
Oh, you're a great girl. And you know you've got a man's point of view.
Ted and I are going to be married and stay married. Aren't we - darling.
Yes, we're going to stay married.
How unpatriotic. A man should be willing to lay down more than one wife for his country.
Say, Romeo, are you packed?
Coming up to finish, Juliet.
You're not eating a thing, Paul. Buck up. There's nothing to worry about.
Miss Jerry, if you don't need me anymore, I've got a date to go to the second show with the butcher.
Are his intentions honorable, Hannah?
I'm afraid they are. He just wants to keep a good customer.

[Referring to a new ring]
Oh, you dear, it's lovely.
Will you think of me every time you look at it?
As though I didn't think of you every second of every minute of every hour of every day.
[Kiss]
Oh, darling.
[Looking at the ring]
Gee, that's slick.
Why haven't I heard from you in a month?
Conscience.
You're not that old fashioned are you?
Now see here, Janice. I was plastered and you know it.
Oh, but you're not such a sterling character when my arms are around you.
Then, she has a right to look at you any way she likes?

[Admitting his infidelity]
Now, see here Jerry. I'm sorry darling, of course. But, there's no sense in overplaying it. There's nothing to it. Oh, come on, snap out of it. It isn't the end of the world, darling. Why, gosh, I don't care a snap of my fingers for any woman in the world but you. If-if I'd killed somebody, you'd go all the way and back again for me. I'd ask you to try and forgive me, if I thought it was the right thing to do. But, that isn't the point. But, darling, you've got to get a broader look at things, that's all. Why, you're out in the world doing a man's work. Was that just a lot of talk about a man's point of view? Oh, please believe me, darling. It doesn't mean a thing. Not a thing! It doesn't make the slightest difference. Come on, snap out of it. Now, pull yourself together.
Porter, how long do we stop at the next station? Long enough to telephone?
Yes sir, if you ain't gonna talk to nobody too far. It's supposed to stop there about six minutes.
What's the matter with you, Jerry?
I'm just trying to hang onto the marvelous latitude of a man's point of view.
What's the matter with me?
So why didn't you answer the wires I sent you?
Oh, there was a lot to think about. And the longer you wait, the more sense you get.
You know, letting things ride the way you did, certainly whipped me plenty. Boy, you know I imagined all sorts of receptions when I got home.
Your cheeriness is amazing.
Well, what do you mean?
You're like a little boy that's stolen some jam. Then, spanked and kissed and happy again.
Ted, let me understand something. When you say that being unfaithful doesn't mean anything, you mean just that, don't you?
Well, what I said was...
Yes, I remember what you said. It doesn't mean a thing.
It can't be true. Why, I always thought you were the most decent thing in the world. It can't be true.
Well, it is.
Husbands should never be late. No, sir. You never know who's sitting on the bench, waiting to take your place when you fall out of the game.
Oh, don't let's make a mess of things like this. Spoil our happiness.

Oh, Ted, don't let's talk about men and women. They do all sorts of things. We've got to live our own life, dear. There's so much of it ahead. I'll never do anything you don't like. I'll never make you sorry, really. I'll forgive you anything, dear. Can't you please forgive me? When I try to look ahead without you; why, everything goes black. I love you, dear. I can't go on without you.
I'm glad I discovered that more than one man in the world while I'm young and they want me. Believe me, I'm not missing anything from now on!
I don't doubt it - once a woman throws down her fences!

The looser they are, the more they get! The best in the world! No responsibility! Well, my dear, I'm gonna find out how they do it! So, look for me in the future where the primroses grow. And catch your man's pride with the rest! And from now on, your the only man in the world that my door is closed to!
Congratulations, my darling, you're free. You're exactly as you were before you were married.
Exactly. All I need is a complete set of young illusions and an innocent expression.
From now on, I take all the hurdles, see all the scenery - and listen to the band play.
I didn't know you had a husband, Jerry?
Ha-ha. I had; but, I haven't.
Let's drink to his health, the infernal fool!
When you have grown old, you will be very, very sorry.
Yes, I know. I shall most likely push back the gray hairs, curse at the wrinkles and say - you did not allow the great Ivan to make love to you and now look at you.
Jerry, darling, what you need is a great romance.
Oh, one more would be the death of me.
You've been trying to forget quite a lot, haven't you, Jerry?
Who told you that?
Oh, nobody. I've just been around New York most of the time.
Oh. Ha-ha. And heard the echo of my misdeeds as I thundered up and down Broadway.
What should an ex-wife do? Spend her days doing good deeds? Going to bed at night with suitable books?
I've worked too hard and played too hard. I take my outings on the subway and my exercise in a nightclub. I belong to the sweet, pure air of 42nd Street and Broadway.
Oh, I'm so fed up. I've made such a wreck of things. Such a good for nothing mess!
Oh, Porter.
Yes sir.
There's only supposed to be one person in drawing room A, isn't there?
Yes sir, boss.
Well, see that's how it is. Get me?
I get chu.
He's got a kick on him like a Missouri mule. Ha!
They want me to spend five years in Japan. You know, we could have a beautiful time. Leave all our mistakes 7,000 miles behind us.
Seven thousand miles - it sounds grand.
Funny, isn't it. How one girl can be bigger than all the tall buildings.
You going to Japan with them, Hannah?
Oh, sure. I want to see where the money's gone. I've paid to foreign missions for the heathen.
Miss Jerry's gave up her job.
Really, she's resigned?
And her firm come right back with an offer of $7,500 a year to go to London. They have branches in Europe.
Hooray for Jerry!
Personally, I'd a darn sight rather go to London than to - Yokohokohame.
What a girl!
It's a New Year in a minute, Ted. All the world gets a new chance.
Don't kid me Jerry. I'd give my right arm for another chance.
I like that right arm. How about putting it around me?
